canonical_explanation.text:
The endocrine system works alongside the nervous system to coordinate and integrate body functions. Endocrine glands are ductless glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream. The major endocrine glands include the hypothalamus, pituitary, pineal, thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, pancreas, thymus, and gonads. The hypothalamus produces releasing and inhibiting hormones that regulate the anterior pituitary. The pituitary gland has two lobes: the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis) secretes GH, PRL, TSH, ACTH, LH, and FSH; the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) stores and releases ADH and oxytocin (produced by the hypothalamus). The thyroid gland secretes T₃ (triiodothyronine), T₄ (thyroxine), and calcitonin. The parathyroid glands secrete PTH (parathyroid hormone). The adrenal gland has two parts: the cortex (secretes cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids) and the medulla (secretes adrenaline and noradrenaline).

The pancreas is both an exocrine and endocrine gland. The islets of Langerhans contain alpha cells (secrete glucagon) and beta cells (secrete insulin). Insulin lowers blood glucose, while glucagon raises it. The gonads (testes and ovaries) secrete sex hormones: testosterone (testes), oestrogen and progesterone (ovaries). The thymus secretes thymosin, important for T-cell differentiation. Hormones act through two mechanisms: peptide hormones bind to membrane receptors and use second messengers like cAMP, while steroid hormones enter the cell and bind to intracellular receptors to regulate gene expression. Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback mechanisms, primarily negative feedback. Common disorders include dwarfism, gigantism, and acromegaly (GH imbalance), goitre and cretinism (thyroid dysfunction), diabetes mellitus (insulin deficiency or resistance), and Addison's disease (adrenal cortex hypofunction).
rules: The hypothalamus produces releasing hormones (e.g., GnRH, TRH, CRH) and inhibiting hormones that control the anterior pituitary.
Anterior pituitary secretes: GH (growth), PRL (prolactin, milk production), TSH (thyroid-stimulating), ACTH (adrenocorticotrophic), LH and FSH (gonadotrophins).
Posterior pituitary stores and releases: ADH (water reabsorption in kidneys) and oxytocin (uterine contractions, milk ejection) — both produced in the hypothalamus.
Thyroid hormones (T₃ and T₄) regulate BMR, growth, and development; calcitonin lowers blood Ca²⁺ by promoting calcium deposition in bones.
PTH raises blood Ca²⁺ by stimulating bone resorption, increased renal reabsorption, and intestinal absorption (via vitamin D activation).
Adrenal cortex: glucocorticoids (cortisol — stress, anti-inflammatory), mineralocorticoids (aldosterone — Na⁺/K⁺ balance), and sex corticoids.
Adrenal medulla: adrenaline and noradrenaline (catecholamines) — fight-or-flight response; increase heart rate, blood pressure, and blood glucose.
Pancreatic islets: insulin (beta cells) lowers blood glucose (promotes glycogenesis, lipogenesis); glucagon (alpha cells) raises blood glucose (promotes glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis).
Peptide hormones act via membrane receptors and second messengers (cAMP); steroid hormones enter the cell and bind to intracellular/nuclear receptors to regulate gene expression.
Negative feedback: high hormone levels inhibit further release of stimulating hormones; e.g., high T₃/T₄ inhibits TSH and TRH release.
GH disorders: excess in childhood = gigantism, excess in adults = acromegaly, deficiency in childhood = pituitary dwarfism.
Thyroid disorders: iodine deficiency = simple goitre; hypothyroidism in infancy = cretinism; in adults = myxoedema; hyperthyroidism = Graves' disease (exophthalmic goitre).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is called the 'master gland' of the endocrine system?
questions.explanation_correct: The pituitary gland is called the 'master gland' because it secretes hormones that control the activity of several other endocrine glands, including the thyroid (via TSH), adrenals (via ACTH), and gonads (via LH and FSH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the hypothalamus controls the pituitary and is sometimes called the 'master of the master gland', the pituitary is traditionally known as the master gland. The thyroid and adrenal glands are target glands controlled by the pituitary.

questions.question_text: The hormones ADH and oxytocin are synthesised in the:
questions.explanation_correct: ADH (antidiuretic hormone/vasopressin) and oxytocin are synthesised by neurosecretory cells of the hypothalamus. They are transported down the axons to the posterior pituitary, where they are stored and released into the blood when needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The anterior pituitary produces its own hormones (GH, PRL, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH). The posterior pituitary only stores and releases ADH and oxytocin but does not synthesise them. The thyroid gland produces T₃, T₄, and calcitonin.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones is NOT secreted by the anterior pituitary?
questions.explanation_correct: Oxytocin is not secreted by the anterior pituitary. It is synthesised in the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary, from where it is released. The anterior pituitary secretes GH, PRL, TSH, ACTH, LH, and FSH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GH, TSH, and PRL are all hormones of the anterior pituitary. Oxytocin is the only option that is released from the posterior pituitary (though synthesised in the hypothalamus).

questions.question_text: The hypothalamus controls the anterior pituitary by secreting:
questions.explanation_correct: The hypothalamus produces specific releasing hormones (e.g., GnRH, TRH, CRH, GHRH) and inhibiting hormones (e.g., somatostatin, dopamine) that are transported via the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, where they regulate hormone secretion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TSH and ACTH are secreted by the anterior pituitary itself, not the hypothalamus. Insulin and glucagon are from the pancreas. Adrenaline and noradrenaline are from the adrenal medulla.

questions.question_text: Calcitonin is secreted by the:
questions.explanation_correct: Calcitonin (or thyrocalcitonin) is secreted by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland. It lowers blood calcium levels by inhibiting bone resorption and promoting calcium deposition in bones. It acts antagonistically to PTH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parathyroid gland secretes PTH (parathyroid hormone), which raises blood calcium. The adrenal gland produces cortisol, aldosterone, and catecholamines. The pituitary produces GH, TSH, ACTH, etc. Calcitonin is specifically from the thyroid.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones acts antagonistically to parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating blood calcium levels?
questions.explanation_correct: Calcitonin from the thyroid gland lowers blood calcium levels by promoting calcium deposition in bones and inhibiting bone resorption. PTH from the parathyroid gland raises blood calcium levels. These two hormones work antagonistically to maintain calcium homeostasis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thyroxine regulates BMR, not calcium directly. Aldosterone regulates sodium and potassium balance. Insulin regulates blood glucose. Calcitonin is the specific antagonist of PTH in calcium regulation.

questions.question_text: The adrenal gland is located on top of each kidney. Its cortex secretes:
questions.explanation_correct: The adrenal cortex has three zones: zona glomerulosa (secretes mineralocorticoids like aldosterone), zona fasciculata (secretes glucocorticoids like cortisol), and zona reticularis (secretes sex corticoids/androgens). The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adrenaline and noradrenaline are secreted by the adrenal medulla, not the cortex. Insulin and glucagon are from the pancreas. TSH and ACTH are from the anterior pituitary.

questions.question_text: The pineal gland secretes melatonin, which primarily regulates:
questions.explanation_correct: Melatonin, secreted by the pineal gland, plays a crucial role in regulating the sleep-wake cycle (circadian rhythm). Its secretion increases during darkness and decreases during light. It also affects skin pigmentation, reproductive function, and body temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood sugar is regulated by insulin and glucagon. Blood pressure is regulated by aldosterone, ADH, and ANF. Bone growth is influenced by GH and thyroid hormones. Melatonin specifically regulates circadian rhythms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct function of parathyroid hormone (PTH)?

options.text: It increases blood calcium levels by stimulating bone resorption

questions.explanation_correct: PTH increases blood calcium levels through three main actions: stimulating osteoclasts to resorb bone (releasing calcium), increasing calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and promoting activation of vitamin D, which enhances calcium absorption from the intestine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcitonin decreases blood calcium, not PTH. Metabolic rate is regulated by thyroid hormones. TSH stimulates the thyroid gland. PTH specifically acts to raise blood calcium levels.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs is correctly matched?
questions.explanation_correct: The thyroid gland secretes three hormones: T₃ (triiodothyronine), T₄ (thyroxine) from the follicular cells, and calcitonin (thyrocalcitonin) from the parafollicular C cells. This is the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ADH and oxytocin are stored in the posterior pituitary (synthesised in hypothalamus), not the anterior pituitary. GH and PRL are from the anterior pituitary, not the posterior. Cortisol and aldosterone are from the adrenal cortex, not the parathyroid.

questions.question_text: The emergency hormones that prepare the body for 'fight or flight' response are secreted by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The adrenal medulla secretes adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), collectively called catecholamines. These are the 'emergency hormones' or 'hormones of fight or flight' that prepare the body for stressful situations by increasing heart rate, blood pressure, respiration, and blood glucose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thyroid gland regulates metabolism. The anterior pituitary secretes tropic hormones. The pancreas secretes insulin and glucagon for blood sugar regulation. The fight-or-flight hormones are specifically from the adrenal medulla.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The hypothalamus is called the 'master of the master gland'.
Reason: The hypothalamus controls the pituitary gland through releasing and inhibiting hormones.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true. The pituitary is the 'master gland' as it controls other endocrine glands. The hypothalamus controls the pituitary through releasing and inhibiting hormones, making it the 'master of the master gland'. The reason correctly explains why the hypothalamus holds this title.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — the hypothalamus is indeed called the master of the master gland. The reason is also true and directly explains the assertion: it controls the pituitary via releasing and inhibiting hormones.

questions.question_text: Thyroxine (T₄) requires which element for its synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine is essential for the synthesis of thyroid hormones T₃ and T₄. The thyroid gland actively concentrates iodine from the blood. Deficiency of iodine in the diet leads to hypothyroidism and enlargement of the thyroid gland (goitre).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is needed for haemoglobin synthesis. Calcium is important for bones and muscle function. Zinc is a cofactor for many enzymes. Iodine is the specific element required for thyroid hormone synthesis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the effect of thyroid hormones?

options.text: They decrease the basal metabolic rate (BMR)
They regulate BMR, support growth and development of the nervous system in children

questions.explanation_correct: Thyroid hormones (T₃ and T₄) increase the basal metabolic rate (BMR), regulate protein, fat, and carbohydrate metabolism, and are essential for normal growth and development, particularly of the brain and nervous system during foetal and early postnatal life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thyroid hormones increase, not decrease, BMR. Lowering blood calcium is the function of calcitonin (a different thyroid product). ACTH from the pituitary stimulates the adrenal cortex, not thyroid hormones.

questions.question_text:
Match the following hormones with their glands of origin:

(i) LH and FSH    (P) Adrenal cortex
(ii) Cortisol    (Q) Posterior pituitary
(iii) ADH    (R) Anterior pituitary
(iv) Melatonin    (S) Pineal gland

Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: LH and FSH are gonadotrophins secreted by the anterior pituitary (R). Cortisol is a glucocorticoid from the adrenal cortex (P). ADH is stored and released from the posterior pituitary (Q). Melatonin is from the pineal gland (S).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each hormone has a specific gland of origin. LH/FSH are anterior pituitary hormones. Cortisol is from the adrenal cortex. ADH is released from the posterior pituitary. Melatonin is from the pineal gland.

questions.question_text: Which hormone is responsible for the 'let-down' reflex during breastfeeding, causing milk ejection?
questions.explanation_correct: Oxytocin (released from the posterior pituitary) causes the contraction of myoepithelial cells around the alveoli of the mammary glands, leading to milk ejection (let-down reflex). Prolactin stimulates milk production, but oxytocin causes milk release.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Prolactin stimulates milk production (lactogenesis) but does not cause milk ejection. Oestrogen and progesterone are involved in mammary gland development during pregnancy but not in the let-down reflex. Oxytocin is the specific hormone for milk ejection.

questions.question_text: Insulin is secreted by the:

options.text: Alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans
Beta cells of the islets of Langerhans
Delta cells of the islets of Langerhans

questions.explanation_correct: Insulin is secreted by the beta (β) cells of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas. It is the only hormone that lowers blood glucose levels. It promotes glucose uptake by cells, glycogenesis (glycogen formation), and lipogenesis (fat synthesis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alpha cells secrete glucagon, which raises blood glucose. Acinar cells produce digestive enzymes (exocrine function). Delta cells secrete somatostatin. Insulin is specifically from beta cells.

questions.question_text: Glucagon acts antagonistically to insulin by:

options.text: Raising blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis
Inhibiting glucose absorption from the intestine

questions.explanation_correct: Glucagon, secreted by the alpha cells of the pancreas, raises blood glucose levels. It stimulates glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen to glucose in the liver) and gluconeogenesis (synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources). This is opposite to the action of insulin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lowering blood glucose is the function of insulin. Glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) is promoted by insulin, not glucagon. Glucagon does not inhibit intestinal glucose absorption. It acts to increase blood glucose levels.

questions.question_text: The thymus gland secretes thymosin, which is important for:
questions.explanation_correct: Thymosin, secreted by the thymus gland, plays a crucial role in the differentiation and maturation of T-lymphocytes, which are essential for cell-mediated immunity. The thymus is most active during childhood and gradually atrophies with age.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood sugar is regulated by insulin and glucagon. Calcium levels are regulated by PTH and calcitonin. The sleep-wake cycle is controlled by melatonin from the pineal gland. Thymosin specifically supports immune system development.

questions.question_text: The male sex hormone testosterone is secreted by the:

options.text: Leydig cells (interstitial cells) of the testes

questions.explanation_correct: Testosterone is secreted by the Leydig cells (interstitial cells), which are located in the spaces between the seminiferous tubules of the testes. Testosterone is responsible for the development of male secondary sexual characters, spermatogenesis, and male reproductive behaviour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sertoli cells provide nutrition to developing sperm cells. Seminiferous tubules are the site of spermatogenesis. The prostate gland contributes to seminal fluid. Testosterone is specifically produced by Leydig cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of insulin in glucose metabolism?

options.text: It promotes breakdown of glycogen in the liver
It promotes cellular uptake of glucose and its conversion to glycogen
It inhibits glucose transport into cells

questions.explanation_correct: Insulin facilitates glucose uptake by cells (especially muscle and fat cells) by promoting the translocation of glucose transporter proteins (GLUT4) to the cell membrane. It also promotes glycogenesis (conversion of glucose to glycogen in the liver and muscles) and lipogenesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glycogen breakdown (glycogenolysis) is promoted by glucagon, not insulin. Gluconeogenesis is also stimulated by glucagon. Insulin promotes glucose transport into cells, not inhibits it.

questions.question_text: The mechanism of action of peptide (water-soluble) hormones involves:

options.text: Entering the cell and binding to nuclear receptors
Binding to membrane receptors and using second messengers like cAMP
Diffusing through the cell membrane to reach the cytoplasm

questions.explanation_correct: Peptide hormones (like insulin, glucagon, GH, and ADH) are water-soluble and cannot cross the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. They bind to specific receptors on the cell surface, which activates an intracellular signalling cascade involving second messengers like cAMP (cyclic AMP).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Entering cells and binding to nuclear receptors is the mechanism of steroid hormones. Peptide hormones do not directly activate DNA transcription. They cannot diffuse through the hydrophobic cell membrane due to their hydrophilic nature.

questions.question_text: Steroid hormones (like cortisol and testosterone) act by:

options.text: Binding to cell surface receptors and generating cAMP
Entering the cell, binding to intracellular receptors, and regulating gene expression
Activating ion channels on the cell membrane
Breaking down into amino acids inside the cell

questions.explanation_correct: Steroid hormones are lipid-soluble and can cross the cell membrane. Inside the cell, they bind to specific intracellular (cytoplasmic or nuclear) receptors. The hormone-receptor complex then acts as a transcription factor, binding to specific DNA sequences and regulating gene expression.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell surface receptors and cAMP signalling are used by peptide hormones. Steroid hormones do not activate ion channels. They are not broken down into amino acids — they are lipid-derived molecules, not proteins.

questions.question_text: The gastrointestinal tract also produces hormones. Which hormone stimulates the secretion of hydrochloric acid in the stomach?
questions.explanation_correct: Gastrin is a hormone produced by G cells of the stomach mucosa. It stimulates the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) by parietal cells and pepsinogen by chief cells. It also stimulates gastric motility.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secretin is produced by the duodenum and stimulates bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas. CCK stimulates the release of pancreatic enzymes and bile from the gallbladder. GIP inhibits gastric acid secretion. Gastrin is the specific stimulant of HCl production.

questions.question_text: Oestrogen is primarily secreted by the:
questions.explanation_correct: Oestrogen is primarily secreted by the growing ovarian follicles (granulosa cells) under the influence of FSH. It is responsible for the development of female secondary sexual characters, regulation of the menstrual cycle, and preparation of the uterus for implantation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The anterior pituitary secretes FSH and LH, which stimulate the ovaries. The adrenal cortex produces small amounts of sex steroids but is not the primary source. The corpus luteum primarily secretes progesterone (and some oestrogen). Ovarian follicles are the main source.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones uses cAMP as a second messenger?
questions.explanation_correct: Glucagon is a peptide hormone that cannot cross the cell membrane. It binds to membrane receptors, which activates adenylyl cyclase, converting ATP to cAMP (cyclic AMP). cAMP then activates protein kinases that trigger glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Testosterone, oestrogen, and cortisol are steroid hormones that cross the cell membrane and bind to intracellular receptors, directly regulating gene expression. They do not use cAMP as a second messenger. Glucagon, being a peptide hormone, uses the cAMP pathway.

questions.question_text: The pancreas is described as a heterocrine gland because it:

options.text: Has both exocrine (digestive enzymes) and endocrine (hormones) functions
Secretes hormones that work both inside and outside the body

questions.explanation_correct: The pancreas is called a heterocrine (mixed) gland because it performs both exocrine and endocrine functions. The exocrine part (acinar cells) produces digestive enzymes secreted through the pancreatic duct. The endocrine part (islets of Langerhans) secretes insulin and glucagon directly into the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pancreas does not secrete only hormones — it also produces digestive enzymes. The hormones work inside the body only. Hormone production is not limited to digestion. Its dual exocrine-endocrine nature makes it heterocrine.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Insulin is the only hormone that lowers blood glucose levels.
Reason: Insulin promotes glucose uptake by cells and glycogenesis.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Insulin is indeed the only hormone in the body that lowers blood glucose levels (several hormones raise it — glucagon, cortisol, GH, adrenaline). It does so by promoting glucose uptake by cells and glycogenesis (conversion of glucose to glycogen), which directly explains its hypoglycaemic effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — insulin is the sole hypoglycaemic hormone. The reason accurately describes its mechanism. Therefore, both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the:
questions.explanation_correct: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum, which forms from the remnants of the ovarian follicle after ovulation. It prepares the endometrium for implantation, maintains pregnancy, and inhibits further ovulation during pregnancy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovarian follicle primarily secretes oestrogen. The anterior pituitary secretes LH and FSH. The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines. Progesterone is the main hormone of the corpus luteum.

questions.question_text: Which of the following GI tract hormones stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice?
questions.explanation_correct: Secretin is produced by the S cells of the duodenal mucosa in response to acidic chyme entering the duodenum. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which neutralises the acidic chyme and provides an optimal pH for pancreatic enzyme action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gastrin stimulates HCl secretion in the stomach. Cholecystokinin stimulates the secretion of enzyme-rich pancreatic juice and bile release. Enterogastrone inhibits gastric secretion. Secretin specifically promotes bicarbonate secretion.

questions.question_text: Erythropoietin (EPO), which stimulates red blood cell production, is produced by the:
questions.explanation_correct: Erythropoietin (EPO) is a hormone produced primarily by the juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney in response to low oxygen levels (hypoxia). It stimulates erythropoiesis (production of red blood cells) in the bone marrow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The liver produces a small amount of EPO but the kidneys are the primary source. The bone marrow is the site of RBC production, not EPO synthesis. The spleen destroys old RBCs but does not produce EPO.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of testosterone?

options.text: Development of male secondary sexual characters
Growth of facial hair and deepening of voice

questions.explanation_correct: Development of mammary glands is NOT a function of testosterone. This is influenced by oestrogen and progesterone. Testosterone is responsible for male secondary sexual characters (facial hair, deep voice, muscular build), stimulation of spermatogenesis, and male reproductive behaviour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Development of male secondary sexual characters, stimulation of spermatogenesis, and growth of facial hair and deepening of voice are all well-established functions of testosterone.

questions.question_text: Diabetes mellitus is caused by a deficiency or reduced effectiveness of:
questions.explanation_correct: Diabetes mellitus is caused by deficiency of insulin (Type 1) or reduced sensitivity of target cells to insulin (Type 2, insulin resistance). Without adequate insulin action, blood glucose levels remain chronically elevated (hyperglycaemia), leading to glucose in the urine (glycosuria).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glucagon excess can raise blood sugar but does not cause diabetes mellitus. Thyroxine affects BMR. ADH deficiency causes diabetes insipidus (not mellitus). Insulin deficiency or resistance is the specific cause of diabetes mellitus.

questions.question_text: Enlargement of the thyroid gland due to iodine deficiency is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Simple (endemic) goitre is the enlargement of the thyroid gland caused by dietary iodine deficiency. Without sufficient iodine, the thyroid cannot produce adequate T₃ and T₄. Low thyroid hormone levels lead to increased TSH secretion, which stimulates the thyroid gland to grow larger in an attempt to compensate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cretinism is hypothyroidism in infants, causing stunted growth and mental retardation. Myxoedema is hypothyroidism in adults. Graves' disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition with exophthalmos. Simple goitre specifically refers to iodine-deficiency-induced thyroid enlargement.

questions.question_text: Excess secretion of growth hormone in adults leads to:
questions.explanation_correct: Acromegaly results from excess GH secretion in adults (after the growth plates have fused). It causes abnormal enlargement of the bones of the face, hands, and feet, thickening of skin, and enlargement of internal organs. In children, excess GH causes gigantism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dwarfism results from GH deficiency in childhood. Gigantism is due to excess GH in childhood (before growth plate closure). Cretinism is caused by thyroid hormone deficiency in infancy. Acromegaly is the adult-onset condition.

questions.question_text: Addison's disease is caused by the hyposecretion of hormones from the:
questions.explanation_correct: Addison's disease is caused by the hyposecretion (underproduction) of hormones from the adrenal cortex, particularly cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, darkening of skin (hyperpigmentation), and electrolyte imbalance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thyroid gland hypofunction causes hypothyroidism. Anterior pituitary hypofunction causes hypopituitarism. Pancreatic hypofunction causes diabetes mellitus. Addison's disease is specifically an adrenal cortex deficiency.

questions.question_text: A child shows stunted physical and mental growth, pot belly, and a protruding tongue. The most likely hormonal deficiency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The symptoms described — stunted physical and mental growth, pot belly, and protruding tongue — are characteristic of cretinism, caused by deficiency of thyroid hormones during infancy and early childhood. Thyroid hormones are essential for normal brain development and growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GH deficiency causes pituitary dwarfism (proportionate short stature without mental retardation). Insulin deficiency causes diabetes mellitus. Testosterone deficiency would not cause these specific symptoms in a child. Cretinism has distinctive features including mental retardation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions is caused by hypersecretion of thyroid hormones?
questions.explanation_correct: Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition that causes hyperthyroidism. Antibodies stimulate the TSH receptors on the thyroid, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones. Symptoms include increased BMR, weight loss, rapid heartbeat, nervousness, and exophthalmos (bulging eyes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myxoedema is hypothyroidism in adults. Cretinism is hypothyroidism in infants. Simple goitre is due to iodine deficiency (hypothyroidism). Graves' disease is the condition specifically caused by excess thyroid hormone production.

questions.question_text: Cushing's syndrome is caused by excess secretion of:
questions.explanation_correct: Cushing's syndrome results from prolonged exposure to excess cortisol (glucocorticoid) from the adrenal cortex. Symptoms include moon face, buffalo hump, central obesity, thin extremities, high blood sugar, hypertension, and muscle weakness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excess insulin would cause hypoglycaemia, not Cushing's syndrome. Excess adrenaline would cause persistent fight-or-flight symptoms. Excess aldosterone causes Conn's syndrome (hyperaldosteronism). Cushing's syndrome is specifically due to excess cortisol.

questions.question_text: A patient has high blood sugar, frequent urination, and excessive thirst. The condition is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: The classic triad of diabetes mellitus includes hyperglycaemia (high blood sugar), polyuria (frequent urination as the kidneys attempt to excrete excess glucose), and polydipsia (excessive thirst due to water loss). This is caused by insulin deficiency or resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diabetes insipidus involves excessive dilute urine but not high blood sugar. Addison's disease causes low blood pressure and fatigue. Cushing's syndrome causes central obesity and moon face. The combination of high blood sugar, polyuria, and polydipsia is characteristic of diabetes mellitus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly differentiates pituitary dwarfism from cretinism?

options.text: Pituitary dwarfism is due to GH deficiency with normal intelligence; cretinism is due to thyroid hormone deficiency with mental retardation
Pituitary dwarfism causes mental retardation; cretinism does not
Both are caused by iodine deficiency

questions.explanation_correct: Pituitary dwarfism is caused by GH deficiency in childhood, resulting in proportionate short stature but normal mental development. Cretinism is caused by thyroid hormone deficiency in infancy, resulting in stunted growth and mental retardation because thyroid hormones are essential for brain development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pituitary dwarfism does not cause mental retardation — intelligence is normal. Cretinism does cause mental retardation. Only cretinism may be related to iodine deficiency (through thyroid hormone deficiency). The key difference is the presence of mental retardation in cretinism.

questions.question_text:
Match the following disorders with their causes:

(i) Gigantism    (P) Excess cortisol
(ii) Goitre    (Q) Excess GH in childhood
(iii) Cushing's syndrome    (R) Hyposecretion of adrenal cortex
(iv) Addison's disease    (S) Iodine deficiency

Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Gigantism (Q) — excess GH in childhood. Goitre (S) — iodine deficiency. Cushing's syndrome (P) — excess cortisol. Addison's disease (R) — hyposecretion of adrenal cortex hormones. Each disorder has a specific hormonal cause.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each disorder has a distinct cause. Gigantism is from excess GH in childhood. Goitre is from iodine deficiency. Cushing's syndrome is from excess cortisol. Addison's disease is from adrenal cortex hypofunction.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Exophthalmic goitre is associated with hyperthyroidism.
Reason: In Graves' disease, excess thyroid hormones cause increased BMR, weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and protrusion of eyeballs.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true. Exophthalmic goitre (Graves' disease) is a form of hyperthyroidism. The excess thyroid hormones cause increased BMR, weight loss, tachycardia (rapid heartbeat), and exophthalmos (protrusion of eyeballs). The reason correctly describes the symptoms and mechanism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — exophthalmic goitre is indeed a hyperthyroid condition. The reason accurately lists the symptoms caused by excess thyroid hormones. Both are true and the reason explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which hormone levels in the blood are maintained within a normal range?
questions.explanation_correct: Negative feedback is the primary mechanism for maintaining hormone homeostasis. When the level of a hormone (or its effect) rises above normal, it inhibits further secretion of the stimulating hormone. For example, high T₃/T₄ inhibits TSH from the pituitary and TRH from the hypothalamus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Positive feedback amplifies a response (e.g., oxytocin during labour) but is rare and not the primary homeostatic mechanism. Neural stimulation alone cannot maintain hormonal balance. Hormone levels are precisely regulated, not randomly fluctuating.

questions.question_text: Hyposecretion of growth hormone during childhood leads to:
questions.explanation_correct: Hyposecretion (deficiency) of growth hormone during childhood results in pituitary dwarfism, characterised by proportionate but stunted growth. The individual has normal intelligence but remains short in stature. GH replacement therapy can be effective if given early.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acromegaly is caused by excess GH in adults. Gigantism is caused by excess GH in children. Cretinism is caused by thyroid hormone deficiency, not GH deficiency. Pituitary dwarfism is the specific result of childhood GH deficiency.

questions.question_text: Which of the following glands decreases in size and function with age?
questions.explanation_correct: The thymus gland is most active during childhood, when it plays a vital role in the development and maturation of T-lymphocytes. It gradually atrophies (decreases in size) with age and is largely replaced by fatty tissue in adults. This is called thymic involution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thyroid, pituitary, and adrenal glands remain functional throughout life, though their activity may change with age. The thymus is unique in that it significantly shrinks and loses much of its function after puberty.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the heart as an endocrine organ is correct?

options.text: The atrial wall secretes ANF (atrial natriuretic factor)

questions.explanation_correct: The atrial wall of the heart produces ANF (atrial natriuretic factor) when blood volume or blood pressure increases. ANF acts on the kidneys to cause vasodilation, promote Na⁺ excretion, and reduce blood volume, thereby lowering blood pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insulin is produced by the pancreas. Erythropoietin is produced by the kidneys. Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid. ANF is the specific hormone produced by the heart.

questions.question_text: Myxoedema is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Myxoedema is the condition caused by hypothyroidism (deficiency of thyroid hormones) in adults. Symptoms include low BMR, weight gain, puffiness of the face, lethargy, cold intolerance, slow speech, and dry skin. The name refers to the mucinous oedema of the skin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hyperthyroidism in adults causes Graves' disease or thyrotoxicosis. Excess GH in adults causes acromegaly. ADH deficiency causes diabetes insipidus. Myxoedema is specifically adult hypothyroidism.

questions.question_text: ACTH (adrenocorticotrophic hormone) from the anterior pituitary primarily stimulates the:
questions.explanation_correct: ACTH (adrenocorticotrophic hormone) acts on the adrenal cortex, specifically stimulating the zona fasciculata to produce glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol. ACTH release is stimulated by CRH (corticotrophin-releasing hormone) from the hypothalamus, especially during stress.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TSH stimulates the thyroid to produce thyroxine. The adrenal medulla is stimulated by sympathetic nervous system, not ACTH. LH and FSH stimulate the gonads. ACTH specifically targets the adrenal cortex.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of positive feedback in the endocrine system?

options.text: High T₃/T₄ levels inhibiting TSH release
Oxytocin stimulating uterine contractions during childbirth, which further stimulates oxytocin release
High cortisol levels inhibiting ACTH release
High blood glucose stimulating insulin secretion, which lowers glucose

questions.explanation_correct: Oxytocin during childbirth is a classic example of positive feedback. Uterine contractions stimulate oxytocin release from the posterior pituitary, and oxytocin further intensifies contractions, which in turn cause more oxytocin release. This cycle continues until delivery is complete.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High T₃/T₄ inhibiting TSH is negative feedback. High cortisol inhibiting ACTH is negative feedback. Insulin lowering blood glucose is also negative feedback. Positive feedback amplifies a response, as seen with oxytocin during labour.
